title: How to Make Apple Cider Baked Doughnuts

steps.headline: Boil and simmer the apple cider.
steps.description: Allow the cider to reduce to 1/2 cup and allow it to cool. During this reducing, enhance the flavor by adding spices and cinnamon sticks in.

steps.headline: Mix the wet ingredients.
steps.description: In a large bowl, beat the sugars, egg, and butter with a stand or hand mixer. Add the reduced apple cider, buttermilk, and vanilla. Whisk the mixture until it's smooth.

steps.headline: Mix the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Use a medium bowl to combine the flour, cinnamon, cloves, baking soda, baking powder, and salt with a metal wire whisk.

steps.headline: Incorporate the two bowls.
steps.description: Sift the dry ingredients into the wet ingredient bowl. Avoid overmixing the batter; it is fine to leave small lumps. For the best results and easier stirring, sift a small amount at a time between stirring.

steps.headline: Allow the doughnuts to cool.
steps.description: Leave them in the pan for a few minutes.

steps.headline: Transfer the doughnuts to a wire cooling rack.
steps.description: Set aside for about 15 to 20 minutes.

text: Making the Batter Boil and simmer the apple cider. Allow the cider to reduce to 1/2 cup and allow it to cool. During this reducing, enhance the flavor by adding spices and cinnamon sticks in. Preheat the oven to 350°F (180°C).  Mix the wet ingredients. In a large bowl, beat the sugars, egg, and butter with a stand or hand mixer. Add the reduced apple cider, buttermilk, and vanilla. Whisk the mixture until it's smooth. Mix the dry ingredients. Use a medium bowl to combine the flour, cinnamon, cloves, baking soda, baking powder, and salt with a metal wire whisk. Incorporate the two bowls. Sift the dry ingredients into the wet ingredient bowl. Avoid overmixing the batter; it is fine to leave small lumps. For the best results and easier stirring, sift a small amount at a time between stirring. Baking the Doughnuts Fill a doughnut pan. Add the batter to the cavities of the pan, about 2/3 full. If you are making doughnut holes, use a mini muffin pan and fill them about 3/4 full. Bake the doughnuts for 10 minutes.  Allow the doughnuts to cool. Leave them in the pan for a few minutes. Transfer the doughnuts to a wire cooling rack. Set aside for about 15 to 20 minutes. Making and Applying the Topping Mix the cinnamon and sugar in a small bowl.  Dip the doughnuts into the melted butter.  Roll the doughnuts into the cinnamon sugar mixture.
